condition.narrative: Delivery of a completed Disbursement Request form, together with the periodic reports required under Section 5.1 of this Agreement, in each case in form and substance satisfactory to MCC, covering the related Disbursement Period.

Each of the Governmentï¿½s representations and warranties set forth in Section 4.1 of this Agreement are true and correct on and as of the date on which the Disbursement Request is submitted and as though made on and as of such date.

Evidence of Tax Exemption Mechanism. MCC is satisfied that the Government has entered into a tax exemption agreement or such other mechanism acceptable to MCC to establish or give effect to Section 4.2(k), and such mechanisms are in full force and effect.

Fiscal Agent Services. Designation of an entity or individual to provide fiscal agent services, as approved by MCC, until such time as the Government provides to MCC a true and complete copy of the Fiscal Agent Agreement, duly executed and in full force and effect, and the Fiscal Agent engaged thereby is mobilized.
If requested by MCC, delivery of a Fiscal Agent Certificate, in form and substance satisfactory to MCC, covering the related Disbursement Period.
If requested by MCC, delivery of a MCA Certificate, in form and substance satisfactory to MCC, covering the related Disbursement Period.
If requested by MCC, delivery of a Procurement Agent Certificate, in form and substance satisfactory to MCC, covering the related Disbursement Period.

Initial Disbursements to a Permitted Account. Prior to an initial Disbursement of any Grant funding to a Permitted Account, a true and complete copy of each Bank Agreement, duly executed and in full force and effect as of the date of the related Disbursement Request.
Interim Fiscal Accountability Plan. Adoption of an Interim Fiscal Accountability Plan acceptable to MCC.

No material breach of any responsibility, covenant or obligation under this Agreement or any other related agreement (including the Bank Agreement, the Fiscal Agent Agreement, the Procurement Agent Agreement and any Service Provider Contract) by any Permitted Designee has occurred and is continuing on and as of the date of the Disbursement Request.

Prior to any disbursement of the Grant for the MCC-Contracted Activities, that would be subject to taxation by the Government but for Section 3.1(a), the Government will have entered into a tax exemption agreement or such other mechanism acceptable to MCC to establish or give effect to Section 4.2(k), and such mechanism will be in full force and effect.

Procurement Agent Services. Designation of an entity or individual to provide procurement agent services, as approved by MCC, until such time as the Government provides to MCC a true and complete copy of the Procurement Agent Agreement, duly executed and in full force and effect, and the Procurement Agent engaged thereby is mobilized.

description.narrative: The Zambia II Farm-to-Market Compact aims to address key constraints within the countryï¿½s agriculture and agro-processing sectors. It will do this through a combination of investments in rural road infrastructure and maintenance; by increasing access to finance for irrigation, electricity, storage facilities, logistics and processing equipment and infrastructure for agriculture; and agricultural policy reform initiatives. Investments in these areas will help the Government of the Republic of Zambia substantially diversify and grow its economy through greater private investment while reducing poverty. The compact includes four projects: (1) the Roads and Access Project, (2) the Asset Finance Project, (3) the Agriculture Policy Reform and Institutional Strengthening Project, and (4) the American Catalyst Facility for Development Project.

Zambia II Compact - Access to Financial Service Project: The Asset Finance Project aims to increase access to finance for investment in energy, irrigation, logistics, processing (EILP) equipment and infrastructure for agriculture value chains for both men and women-owned agricultural small and medium enterprises (Agri-SMEs) and project developers. The Agri-SME Asset Financing Activity (AAF Activity) aims to improve Agri-SMEs access to affordable financing by providing funding for: 1. Performance based grants to financial service providers (FSPs) and equipment providers (EPs) to incentivize lending and finance to Agri-SMEs 2. Design of an impact-investing funding vehicle that raises funds for Zambian agri-enterprises 3. Technical assistance to build capacity for lending to Agri-SMEs and to Agri-SME borrowers to improve financial literacy, business planning, and linkages to market opportunities. The Zambia Project Preparation Facility for EILP (ZAMPPF Activity) aims to increase the number of EILP infrastructure projects that support agriculture value chains to reach financial close by providing: 1. Technical assistance to project developers (e.g., GRZ and private developers) to develop bankable EILP infrastructure projects; 2. Technical assistance and capacity building for public and private project developers.

description.narrative: Zambia II Compact - Agriculture Project: The Agriculture Policy Reform and Institutional Strengthening Project aims to improve institutional capacity to facilitate private sector production and trade in grains. It will enhance the public sectorï¿½s operational efficiency and its ability to develop and implement policies, regulations, and procedures conducive to private sector engagement while also strengthening ancillary market support institutions such as a commodity exchange and a reliable market information hub.

condition.narrative: Further details on conditions precedent affecting this activity can be found in the top-level parent activities.

description.narrative: Zambia II Compact - Agriculture Project - Institutional Strengthening Activity: The Ministry of Agriculture Institutional Strengthening Activity aims to strengthen the Ministry of Agricultureï¿½s capacity to develop and implement reforms. This shall be achieved through the delivery of an efficient export and import permitting system, the development of a plan to establish and help operationalize a warehouse licensing authority as provided by the Agricultural Credits Act, and the establishment of a public-private agricultural marketing council once the Agricultural Marketing Bill is adopted. This Activity shall support the provision of capacity building activities in order to support the implementation of the new legal framework, supported by the Project, including the ability to develop subsequent regulations. TA support shall be provided to the Ministry of Agricultureï¿½s different departments responsible for policy and planning (PPD), agribusiness and marketing (ABM), and plant quarantine and phytosanitary service (PQPS) to assess new responsibilities and develop the capacity to deliver improved services.
Zambia II-Compact-Agriculture Project-Institutional Strengthening Activity Account Budget Item

usg:usg-activity.usg:purpose-statement: Zambia II Compact - Agriculture Project - Institutional Strengthening Activity: The Ministry of Agriculture Institutional Strengthening Activity aims to strengthen the Ministry of Agricultureï¿½s capacity to develop and implement reforms. This shall be achieved through the delivery of an efficient export and import permitting system, the development of a plan to establish and help operationalize a warehouse licensing authority as provided by the Agricultural Credits Act, and the establishment of a public-private agricultural marketing council once the Agricultural Marketing Bill is adopted. This Activity shall support the provision of capacity building activities in order to support the implementation of the new legal framework, supported by the Project, including the ability to develop subsequent regulations. TA support shall be provided to the Ministry of Agricultureï¿½s different departments responsible for policy and planning (PPD), agribusiness and marketing (ABM), and plant quarantine and phytosanitary service (PQPS) to assess new responsibilities and develop the capacity to deliver improved services.

description.narrative: Zambia II Compact - Agriculture Project - Capacity Building Activity: The Food Reserve Agency Institutional Strengthening Activity aims to improve the Food Reserve Agencyï¿½s (ï¿½FRAï¿½) operational capacity in fulfilling its main functions of efficiently managing the strategic grain reserves, encouraging greater involvement of the private sector in grain trading, making timely payment for purchases, and providing an appropriate price stabilization function. This Activity shall also support capacity building activities that enhance collaboration with other entities involved in assessing, monitoring, and analyzing food security, poverty, and vulnerability to strengthen FRAï¿½s policy response and mitigation functions. FRAï¿½s response to vulnerability assessments shall include the deployment of responsive FRA policies and systems, as well as collaboration and communication with other agencies involved in welfare response. The strengthening of FRAï¿½s institutional framework shall be achieved through a combination of procedural changes, operational improvements, systems development, and staff capacity building for: 1) food security and vulnerability response and collaboration; 2) management of strategic grain reserves; 3) upgrading maize purchase modalities; 4) optimizing and streamlining warehouse usage; and 5) mitigating market price volatility.

usg:usg-activity.usg:purpose-statement: Zambia II Compact - Agriculture Project - Capacity Building Activity: The Food Reserve Agency Institutional Strengthening Activity aims to improve the Food Reserve Agencyï¿½s (ï¿½FRAï¿½) operational capacity in fulfilling its main functions of efficiently managing the strategic grain reserves, encouraging greater involvement of the private sector in grain trading, making timely payment for purchases, and providing an appropriate price stabilization function. This Activity shall also support capacity building activities that enhance collaboration with other entities involved in assessing, monitoring, and analyzing food security, poverty, and vulnerability to strengthen FRAï¿½s policy response and mitigation functions. FRAï¿½s response to vulnerability assessments shall include the deployment of responsive FRA policies and systems, as well as collaboration and communication with other agencies involved in welfare response. The strengthening of FRAï¿½s institutional framework shall be achieved through a combination of procedural changes, operational improvements, systems development, and staff capacity building for: 1) food security and vulnerability response and collaboration; 2) management of strategic grain reserves; 3) upgrading maize purchase modalities; 4) optimizing and streamlining warehouse usage; and 5) mitigating market price volatility.

description.narrative: Zambia II Compact - Agriculture Project - Ancillary Ag Market Strengthening Activity: The Establishment and Strengthening of Ancillary Agricultural Market Support Institutions Activity aims to build transparency and trust among grain market players by establishing an independent market observatory that collects timely and accurate data on stocks and prices and conducts relevant market analysis for the benefit of public sector policy makers and private sector economic actors, enhancing crop forecasting, and supporting the commodity exchange.

description.narrative: Zambia II Compact - Roads Project: The Roads and Access Project aims to decrease transportation costs in prioritized agricultural corridors. The project will improve road condition and climate resilience, improve access of residents, particularly women, to the road network and markets, and improve road asset management to ensure the sustainability of investments. The Improving Roads Activity aims to improve road conditions, quality, access, and climate resilience for selected segments within the identified agricultural corridors through the design, construction, expansion, rehabilitation, upgrades, and/or strengthening of selected roadways. The Improving Access Activity aims to create and/or improve connections (physical and non-physical) to markets and agricultural activities for rural populations within prioritized agricultural corridors. The Strengthening Zambian Road Management Activity aims to improve road asset management with an emphasis on road maintenance investments in Zambia.

description.narrative: This compact aims to address one of Zambia's most binding constraints to economic growth through infrastructure investment in Lusaka, the rapidly urbanizing capital. The compact will invest in water supply, sanitation and drainage infrastructure with the goal of decreasing the incidence and prevalence of water-related disease, productive days lost due to disease and time to collect water, cost of water and new sanitation, and business and residential flood losses. The compact will also support the Government of Zambia's ongoing water sector reform efforts by strengthening partner institutions. More than 1 million Zambians are expected to benefit from the compact.

title.narrative: Zambia Compact Monitoring and Evaluation Plan
Zambia STAR Report: Full Program Lifecycle Report

condition.narrative: I.1 Compact and PIA ratified by GRZ cabinet and domesticated by parliament
I.2 PIA signed by GRZ and MCC

I.3 Delivery of GRZ certificate signed and dated by GRZ Principal Representative confirming that the GRZ has completed all domestic requirements to EIF and all EIF CPs satisfied, attaching:Attachment A- Complete, certified copies of all decrees, legislation, etc. relating to domestic requirements for the compact to enter into force (see 1.1)Attachment B- LWSC amended Articles;- SCAP;- Sustainability AgreementAttachment C- Incumbency and Specimen Signature certificate for GRZ Principal Rep.
I.4 Delivery of GRZ Legal Opinion from Attorney General, in form and substance satisfactory to MCC
I.5 MCC must determine that, after signature of the Compact, the GRZ has not engaged in a pattern of actions inconsistent with the eligibility criteria for MCC Funding
I.6 GRZ delivers GRZ Sanitation Action Plan, consistent with LWSC's "Sanitation Marketing Program", which plan must be in form and substance satisfactory to MCC

I.7 GRZ delivers a certified copy of LWSC Shareholder resolution demonstrating to MCC's satisfaction that at least 50% of LWSC's Retained Earnings will be reserved for asset renewal and capital expansion
I.8 MCC has determined that GRZ has verified a reasonable amount of its payment obligations to LWSC and has paid such amount to MCC's satisfaction
I.9 GRZ and LWSC enter into LWSC Sustainability Agreement
I.10 Delivery of GRZ Principal Rep letter confirming that it has completed its domestic requirements for EIF
I.11 Delivery of MCC Principal Rep letter confirming that it has completed its domestic requirements for EIF
I.12 Update/finalize due diligence book
I.13 Fund Cite
I.14 Case-Zablocki: Compact Executed - transmittal letter to DoS for Compact, background statement and e-filing
I.15 Case-Zablocki: Exchange of Letters - certified copies of Exchange of Letters provided to DoS
II.1 The Compact has entered into force as provided in Article 7 of the Compact
II.2 Each of the Officers (e.g. Key Staff) has been selected and engaged by MCA-Zambia and approved by MCC

II.3 (i) MCA-Zambia has delivered a duly executed certificate with the following attachments (the Initial DR Certificate): Certified copy of MCA-Zambia Articles of Association and Certificate of Incorporation
II.3 (ii) MCA-Zambia has delivered a duly executed certificate with the following attachments (the Initial DR Certificate): List of current members of Board

II.3 (iii) MCA-Zambia has delivered a duly executed certificate with the following attachments (the Initial DR Certificate): Certified copy of Board resolutions approving/authorizing execution of Material Agreements, in form and substance satisfactory to MCC
II.3 (iv) MCA-Zambia has delivered a duly executed certificate with the following attachments (the Initial DR Certificate): Incumbency certificate for Chair of Board and CEO
II.3 (v) MCA-Zambia has delivered a duly executed certificate with the following attachments (the Initial DR Certificate): Certified copy of organigram for MCA-Zambia
II.3 (vi) MCA-Zambia has delivered a duly executed certificate with the following attachments (the Initial DR Certificate): Certified copy of approved salary grid for MCA-Zambia
II.3 (vii) MCA-Zambia has delivered a duly executed certificate with the following attachments (the Initial DR Certificate): Certified copies of employment contracts for each Officer (i.e. Key Staff)
II.4 MCA-Zambia has developed and adopted the FAP
II.5 (i) MCA-Zambia has developed and adopted a complete Implementation Plan, which includes: Work Plan for Program
II.5 (ii) MCA-Zambia has developed and adopted a complete Implementation Plan, which includes: Detailed Financial Plan
II.5 (iii) MCA-Zambia has developed and adopted a complete Implementation Plan, which includes: Audit Plan
II.5 (iv) MCA-Zambia has developed and adopted a complete Implementation Plan, which includes: Procurement Plan
II.6 (i) MCA-Zambia has executed Implementing Entity Agreements with: LWSC Implementing Entity Agreement
II.6 (ii) MCA-Zambia has executed Implementing Entity Agreements with: LCC Implementing Entity Agreement

LWSC will submit a status report on measures acceptable to MCC that are being taken to reduce or eliminate reoccurring arrears at each government institution. LWSC may also seek NWASCO approval for an extra-ordinary rate increase based on non-payment of water bills and sanitation fees by each government institution.
II.8 (i) Submission of Disbursement Request, including: Narrative Report
II.8 (ii) Submission of Disbursement Request, including: Quarterly Financial Report
II.8 (iii) Submission of Disbursement Request, including: Detailed Financial Plan
II.8 (iv) Submission of Disbursement Request, including: Procurement Performance Report
II.8 (v) Submission of Disbursement Request, including: Indicator Tracking Table
II.8 (vi) Submission of Disbursement Request, including: Conditions Precedent Report
II.9 Copies of any reports received from any technical auditors engaged by MCA-Zambia since the previous disbursements of MCC Funding
II.10 Procurement Agent Certificate
II.11 Fiscal Agent Certificate
II.12 Applicable CPs from Schedule 2 to PIA
II.13 No material default or breach of any covenant, obligation or responsibility of GRZ, MCA or any other GRZ entity
II.14 Funded activities do not violate any applicable law or regulation

II.15 The Implementation Plan Documents and the FAP are current and updated and are in form and substance satisfactory to MCC, and there has been satisfactory progress on the components of the Implementation Plan
II.16 There has been satisfactory progress on the M&E Plan and the Social and Gender Integration Plan for the Program

II.17 There has been no material negative finding in any financial audit report delivered in accordance with the Compact and Audit Plan, for the prior two quarters (or such other period as the Audit Plan may require)
II.18 Any Taxes paid with MCC Funding through the date ninety (90) days prior to the start of the applicable Disbursement Period have been reimbursed by the GRZ
II.19 The GRZ has satisfied any payment obligation required under the Compact, PIA or Supp. Agreement
II.20 MCC does not have grounds for concluding that any matter certified to it in the related MCA Disbursement Certificate, PA Certificate or FA Certificate is not as certified
II.21 No act, omission, condition, or event has occurred that would be the basis for MCC to suspend or terminate, in whole or in part, MCC Funding in accordance with Section 5.1 of the Compact
II.22 Each of the Officers remains engaged, or if a position is vacant, MCA is actively engaged, to MCC's satisfaction, in recruiting a replacement
II.23 MCA-Zambia has complied in all material respects with its obligation to establish a BCS and an M&E Plan
II.24 LWSC continues to reserve at least 50% of the LWSC Retained Earnings and the related Board resolution remains in full force and effect
II.25 LWSC has allocated, expended or committed an appropriate amount of the reserved LWSC's Retained Earnings for asset renewal and capital expansion
II.26 LWSC has allocated, expended or committed an appropriate amount of funding for the repair and maintenance of the water supply and sanitation infrastructure under its control
II.27 The LWSC Sustainability Agreement is in full force and effect and there has been no default or breach thereunder
II.28 NWASCO continues to operate autonomously and independently from the GRZ with authority to modify tariffs without GRZ approval or review

Prior to the 1st Disbursement that includes any funding for construction of the Project; and each Disbursement hereafter, MCA-Zambia has submitted evidence that an ESIA, an ESMP, HSMP or RAP has been developed and adopted with respect to the Project; and MCA-Zambia is in compliance with its requirements.
Prior to the 2nd Disbursement MCA-Zambia must submit a Social and Gender Integration Plan (SGIP) and it must be approved by MCC.
Prior to any Disbursement in year 5 of the Compact Term, Compact Closure Plan (CCP) and it must be approved by MCC.
Prior to the 1st Disbursement of Program Funding for the construction of sanitation infrastructure, GRZ will deposit $800,000 into the LWSC Sanitation Connection Fund.

Prior to the 2nd Disbursement and each subsequent Disbursement after construction for the sanitation project has started LWSC has submitted evidence of the amount remaining in the LWSC Sanitation Connection Fund or that such funds have been appropriately expended in accordance with the SCAP.

Prior to any Disbursement occurring after the 1 year anniversary of signing the first sanitation construction contract, GRZ will deposit an additional $400,000 into the LWSC Sanitation Connection Fund.
Prior to any Disbursement occurring 2 years after the signing of the first sanitation construction contract, GRZ will deposit an additional $400,000 into the LWSC Sanitation Connection Fund.

Prior to any Disbursement of Program Funding on or after the commencement of year five (5) of the Compact Term, the Government will have submitted to MCC a report in form and substance satisfactory to MCC demonstrating that the GRZ Sanitation Connection Action Plan is being successfully implemented, utilizing the LWSC Sanitation Connection Funds, to assist eligible beneficiaries obtain household connections to the sanitation infrastructure assets financed under the Compact.

Prior to any Disbursement occurring after the availability of recommendations or findings regarding preventative or corrective maintenance, LWSC has completed any required preventative and corrective maintenance.

Prior to the initial Disbursement of Program Funding that includes, in whole or in part, any funding for the construction of drainage infrastructure, LCC will have adopted a binding budget allocation for the then current fiscal year equal to at least One Million Five Hundred Thousand United States Dollars (US$1,500,000) (the "LCC Drainage Maintenance Amount") for use by LCC for the repair and maintenance of the drainage infrastructure assets for which it is responsible and for the establishment and management of an autonomous solid waste management utility.

Prior to the initial Disbursement of Program Funding in each subsequent fiscal year during the Compact Term that includes, in whole or in part, any funding for the construction of drainage infrastructure, LCC will have adopted a binding budget allocation for such fiscal year equal to at least the LCC Drainage Maintenance Amount, indexed annually for inflation in a manner acceptable to MCC, for use by LCC for the repair and maintenance of the drainage infrastructure assets for which it is responsible and for the establishment and the management of an autonomous solid waste management utility.

Prior to any Disbursement of funds for the Institutional Strengthening Activity GRZ and MCC have agreed on the written procedures to govern the identification of potential Grant recipients. Approval from MCC regarding written procedures is needed.
1) MCA-Zambia has delivered to MCC an Interim Fiscal Accountability Plan (IFAP)
2) MCA-Zambia has delivered a CIF Procurement Plan acceptable to MCC
3a) The Government (or MCA-Zambia) has delivered to MCC the following documents, in form and substance satisfactory to MCC: Disbursement Request
3b) The Government (or MCA-Zambia) has delivered to MCC the following documents, in form and substance satisfactory to MCC: Quarterly Financial Report
3c) The Government (or MCA-Zambia) has delivered to MCC the following documents, in form and substance satisfactory to MCC: Detailed Financial Plan
3d) The Government (or MCA-Zambia) has delivered to MCC the following documents, in form and substance satisfactory to MCC: Procurement Performance Report
3e) The Government (or MCA-Zambia) has delivered to MCC the following documents, in form and substance satisfactory to MCC: Conditions Precedent Report
3f) The Government (or MCA-Zambia) has delivered to MCC the following documents, in form and substance satisfactory to MCC: MCA-Zambia certificate
3g) The Government (or MCA-Zambia) has delivered to MCC the following documents, in form and substance satisfactory to MCC: FA Certificate
3h) The Government (or MCA-Zambia) has delivered to MCC the following documents, in form and substance satisfactory to MCC: PA Certificate
4) If any CIF proceeds to be deposited in Bank Account, MCC has received satisfactory evidence that (i) The Bank Agreement has been executed and (ii) The Permitted Accounts have been established

5) Appointment of entity or individual to provide Fiscal Agent services as approved by MCC until such time as the Government provides to MCC a true and complete copy of a Fiscal Agent Agreement, duly executed and in full force and effect, and the Fiscal Agent engaged thereby is mobilized.

6) Appointment of entity or individual to provide Procurement Agent services as approved by MCC until such time as the Government provides to MCC a true and complete copy of a Procurement Agent Agreement, duly executed and in full force and effect, and the Procurement Agent engaged thereby is mobilized.

7) Each activity being funded by such CIF Disbursement is necessary, advisable, or is otherwise consistent with the goal of facilitating the implementation of the Compact and will not violate any applicable law or regulation

8) There has been no violation of, and the use of the requested funds for the purposes requested will not violate, the limitations on the use or treatment of MCC Funding set forth in Section 2.7 of the Compact or any applicable law or regulation

9) No material default or breach of any covenant, obligation, or responsibility of the Government, MCA-Zambia, or any Government entity has occurred or is continuing under the Compact or any other Supplemental Agreement

10) Any Taxes paid with MCC Funding through the date ninety (90) days prior to the start of the applicable Disbursement Period have been reimbursed by the Government in full in accordance with the Compact.

11) The Government has satisfied all of its payment obligations, including any insurance, indemnification, tax payments or other obligations, and contributed all resources required of it under the Compact and any other Supplemental Agreement

12) For any CIF Disbursement occurring concurrently with or after the initial Disbursement of Program Funding in accordance with Section 3.3 and 3.4 of the Program Implementation Agreement: MCC is satisfied, in its sole discretion, that (i) MCC has received copies of any reports due from any technical consultants (including environmental auditors engaged by MCA-Zambia) for any Activity since the previous Disbursement Request, and all such reports are in form and substance satisfactory to MCC; (ii) The Implementation Plan Documents and Fiscal Accountability Plan are current and updated and are in form and substance satisfactory to MCC, and there has been progress satisfactory to MCC on the components of the Implementation Plan for any relevant projects or Activities related to such CIF Disbursement; (iii) There has been progress satisfactory to MCC on the M&E Plan and Social and Gender Integration Plan for the Program or relevant Project or Activity and substantial compliance with the requirements of the M&E Plan and Social and Gender Integration Plan (including the targets set forth therein and any applicable reporting requirements set forth therein for the relevant Disbursement Period); (iv) There has been no material negative finding in any financial audit report delivered in accordance with this Compact and the Audit Plan, for the prior two quarters (or such other period as the Audit Plan may require); (v) MCC does not have grounds for concluding that any matter certified to it in the related MCA Disbursement Certificate, the Fiscal Agent Disbursement Certificate or the Procurement Agent Disbursement Certificate is not as certified; and (vi) If any of the officers or key staff of MCA-Zambia have been removed or resigned and the position remains vacant, MCA-Zambia is actively engaged in recruiting a replacement.

description.narrative: Zambia - Program Administration and Control - FISCAL AND PROCUREMENT AGENTS activity: Through a competitive process approved by MCC, the Government has appointed a fiscal agent (the "Fiscal Agent") to provide fiscal agent services to MCA-Zambia. The Fiscal Agent will provide a broad range of financial management services required by MCA-Zambia to implement the Program, including funds control, disbursement documentation and management, cash management and accounting. Through a competitive process approved by MCC, the Government has appointed a procurement agent (the "Procurement Agent") to provide procurement agent services to MCA-Zambia. The Procurement Agent will administer all Program and administrative procurements, and provide specified procurement appropriate activities required by MCA-Zambia to implement the Program.

description.narrative: Zambia - Water Supply And Sanitation Project: The objective of the Project (the "Project Objective") was to expand access to, and improve the reliability of, water supply and sanitation, and improve drainage services in select urban and peri-urban areas of the city of Lusaka in order to decrease the incidence of water-borne and water-related diseases, generate time savings for households and businesses and reduce non-revenue water in the water supply network. This project was used in the past for accounting purposes but it is not currently an active project for the program. It has no funds either committed or disbursed against it.

title.narrative: Water Supply, Sanitation and Drainage Project

description.narrative: Zambia - Water Supply, Sanitation and Drainage Project: This activity supports infrastructure managed by the Lusaka Water and Sewerage Company and Lusaka City Council. A key focus is rehabilitation of Lusaka's water supply network, including reducing non-revenue water. It also will expand portions of the city's water supply network; rehabilitate and expand portions of the sewer networks; and improve drainage infrastructure.

description.narrative: Zambia - Water Supply, Sanitation and Drainage Project - Infrastructure Activity: The Activity consists of a series of infrastructure improvements to prioritized water supply, sanitation and drainage assets in Lusaka. Specifically, the Infrastructure Activity includes the following sub-activities: (i) Core Water Network Rehabilitation. This sub-activity is designed to rehabilitate the core water supply network in Lusaka in order to upgrade key treatment and distribution centers and distribution lines and to reduce NRW. (ii) Chelston Distribution Line Rehabilitation and Expansion. This subactivity is designed to expand the water supply network serving the Mtendere, Kamanga, Kwamwena and Ndeke-Vorna Valley areas of Lusaka. (iii) Chelston and Kaunda Square Sewer sheds Rehabilitation and Expansion. This sub-activity is designed to expand the sanitation network in the targeted areas. (iv) Central Distribution Line Rehabilitation and Expansion. This sub activity is designed to expand the water supply network serving the Ng'ombe, SOS East and Chipata areas of Lusaka. (v) Bombay Drain Improvements. This sub-activity is designed to reduce flooding through infrastructure improvements to the Bombay drain, which conveys the runoff from the majority of the downtown business district areas of Lusaka.
Lusaka Province
Capital of Zambia, Lusaka

usg:usg-activity.usg:purpose-statement: Zambia - Water Supply, Sanitation and Drainage Project - Infrastructure Activity: The Activity consists of a series of infrastructure improvements to prioritized water supply, sanitation and drainage assets in Lusaka. Specifically, the Infrastructure Activity includes the following sub-activities: (i) Core Water Network Rehabilitation. This sub-activity is designed to rehabilitate the core water supply network in Lusaka in order to upgrade key treatment and distribution centers and distribution lines and to reduce NRW. (ii) Chelston Distribution Line Rehabilitation and Expansion. This subactivity is designed to expand the water supply network serving the Mtendere, Kamanga, Kwamwena and Ndeke-Vorna Valley areas of Lusaka. (iii) Chelston and Kaunda Square Sewer sheds Rehabilitation and Expansion. This sub-activity is designed to expand the sanitation network in the targeted areas. (iv) Central Distribution Line Rehabilitation and Expansion. This sub activity is designed to expand the water supply network serving the Ng'ombe, SOS East and Chipata areas of Lusaka. (v) Bombay Drain Improvements. This sub-activity is designed to reduce flooding through infrastructure improvements to the Bombay drain, which conveys the runoff from the majority of the downtown business district areas of Lusaka.

description.narrative: Zambia - Water Supply, Sanitation and Drainage Project - Institutional Strengthening Activity: This activity will support infrastructure managed by the Lusaka Water and Sewerage Company (LWSC), the utility primarily responsible for managing the city's water and sanitation infrastructure, as well as the Lusaka City Council (LCC), the local government entity responsible for managing Lusaka's drainage infrastructure. A major portion of the investment is focused on the rehabilitation of Lusaka's core water supply network, including components designed specifically to reduce nonrevenue water. This activity also includes interventions designed to expand the city's water supply network, rehabilitate and enlarge select sewer networks, improve select drainage infrastructure, and provide support for engineering and resettlement professional services. Each of the water supply and sanitation components was selected based on investment master plans and feasibility studies. These chart a three-phase, $3 billion plan that will allow Lusaka to meet the needs of its population through 2035. The drainage component was selected based on the results of priorities identified in a separate comprehensive urban development plan funded by the Japanese International Cooperation Agency (JICA).
Capital of Zambia, Lusaka
Capital of Zambia, Lusaka

usg:usg-activity.usg:purpose-statement: Zambia - Water Supply, Sanitation and Drainage Project - Institutional Strengthening Activity: This activity will support infrastructure managed by the Lusaka Water and Sewerage Company (LWSC), the utility primarily responsible for managing the city's water and sanitation infrastructure, as well as the Lusaka City Council (LCC), the local government entity responsible for managing Lusaka's drainage infrastructure. A major portion of the investment is focused on the rehabilitation of Lusaka's core water supply network, including components designed specifically to reduce nonrevenue water. This activity also includes interventions designed to expand the city's water supply network, rehabilitate and enlarge select sewer networks, improve select drainage infrastructure, and provide support for engineering and resettlement professional services. Each of the water supply and sanitation components was selected based on investment master plans and feasibility studies. These chart a three-phase, $3 billion plan that will allow Lusaka to meet the needs of its population through 2035. The drainage component was selected based on the results of priorities identified in a separate comprehensive urban development plan funded by the Japanese International Cooperation Agency (JICA).
